  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: Trailer from 0793 was unloading from 5:40 to 6:40 package was separated for potential water damage, package was visually inspected poorly, was inbounded 36 mins after. Package was discovered at 16:47 when doing a dock walk, package was found wet. Package had been actively leaking for 10 hours. When package was discovered an inspection was done, corrective measure was done to stop leakage. DescribePack: Loose caps DurationRel: 10 and MitigateEffect: Caps were tightened to prevent extra leakage

item.title: Report E-2023060501
item.description:
Report E-2023060501

Identified by scraper @ 2023-07-07T18:12:22+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-06-20
  • City: HOUSTON
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal LHO experienced a UN3532 ROCRYL 410 (HPMA-LA) release from (2) 55-gallon metal drums. ERTS dispatched contactors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 69-gallons of product released to a 200' x 8' combined area of the trailer floor, concrete dock floor, and asphalt lot below due to a forklift puncture to the drums. Absorbents were deployed and worked into the impacted areas to collect all free-standing product. Hand tools were utilized to collect all hardened material. Each damaged drum was overpacked into a 95-gallon poly drum. All cleanup debris was containerized into (2) 55-gallon poly drums. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report I-2023060097
item.description:
Report I-2023060097

Identified by scraper @ 2023-07-07T18:12:22+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-05-17
  • City: San Antonio
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: AMERICAN AIRLINES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Upon arrival of American Airlines flight 1961 into San Antonio(SAT), Ramp personnel could smell a strong fuel odor upon entering the forward cargo compartment to offload 1,500 lbs of U.S. Mail. Many mail bags and boxes looked soaked. The affected bags were offloaded onto the ramp. The U.S. Postal Inspector arrived an hour after arrival of the flight and was able to determine the bag containing the source of the leak which was a plastic 16 oz bottle of Toyota fuel system treatment. The bottle had been mailed in a bubble wrap envelope and the entire contents of the bottle had leaked due to the pressure differential plus the bottle being under pressure from the weight of mail loaded on top of it. Heritage Environmental had been contacted and arrived to clean up the spill in the cargo compartment. Aircraft Maintenance was also called to inspect for Leakage below the floorboards. The seals around the affected floorboards were intact so no Leakage was detected below the floor of the cargo compartment. The aircraft was out of service for 6 plus hours causing a delay of the outbound flight back to DFW.

  • Description: On 5/17/23, A Univar Solutions driver made a delivery to a customer. Upon being spotted, driver checked with the customer operator on the tank level and was told it was at 60% capacity and that the 2492 gal load would fit. Customer operator informed the driver that there were no site gauges but he would monitor the tank fill from the top. After 20 mins, the operator yelled out to the driver to shut off the pump. The customer operator informed the driver that he'd made an error and was distracted, which lead to the tank being overfilled. Material was contained within the containment area. Customer operator took ownership of the overflow error. Estimate 15 gallons of methanol spilled in containment. No injuries. Spill was cleaned up. Note: Failure code selected was most representative of the incident.

  • Description: On May 25, 2023, two (2) 5-gallon containers of uN1263 were damaged in a load shift and released approximately three (3) gallons of product to the trailer floor and adjacent cargo. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from HazMat Special Services (HSS) to remediate the impacted surfaces. HSS personnel deployed granular absorbents to the release and worked them in using hand tools. The crew then overpacked the damaged containers in one (1) 95-gallon drum for disposal. HSS containerized the spent absorbents in one (1) 55-gallon drum for disposal.

item.title: Report E-2023050558
item.description:
Report E-2023050558

Identified by scraper @ 2023-07-07T18:12:22+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-05-17
  • City: LAREDO
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: RANGER LANDSTAR INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On May 17, 2023, at 1051 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Landstar personnel in Laredo, Texas regarding the release of approximately 175 gallons of IMP-DCP-2018 Emulsion Breaker (Flammable liquid, n.o.s., (Xylene, Ethylbenzene)UN1993, 3, III) from (1) 275-gallon plastic tote. The release was reportedly due to a puncture and was contained to a 10' x 53' area of the trailer floor and continuing on to a 50' x 20' area of a gravel and dirt parking lot. No drains or waterways were affected by the release. Contractors were dispatched to clean up the release using absorbents and the proper PPE. The remaining product in the damaged tote was transferred to a new tote and then forwarded on to the consignee. All waste debris generated was containerized in (3) 55-gallon poly drums and all impacted soil was containerized in (3) cardboard cubic yard boxes. All waste containers were then taken offsite by contractors for proper disposal.

  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal LHW experienced a battery acid release from a 1994-pound UN2794 battery. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 15-gallons of product released to a 6' x 10' area of the trailer floor and 6' x 10' area of the asphalt lot due to the pallet failing, dropping the battery. Absorbents and neutralizer were deployed and worked into the impacted areas. All cleanup debris was collected into (2) 55-gallon poly drums. The damaged battery was secured to a pallet. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

It does not look like there was anything holding the bottom together. DescribePack: The failure was that someone put it on the conveyer belt without giving it to the driver. DurationRel: 2 and MitigateEffect: was put into plastic bags and taken to the hazmat cage

  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal LHO experienced a UN1789 Chem Aqua 65605 release from a 5-gallon poly jerrican due to a nail puncture. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 5-gallons of product released to an 8' x 10' area of the trailer and dock floor due to a nail puncture. Oil dri and Kolorsafe neutralizer were deployed and worked into the impacted areas. The damaged pail and cleanup debris were containerized into a 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2023050082
item.description:
Report E-2023050082

Identified by scraper @ 2023-07-07T18:12:22+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-05-02
  • City: DEER PARK
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: RANGER LANDSTAR INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On May 2, 2023, at 1230 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Landstar personnel in Deer Park, Texas regarding the release of approximately 1 quart of Biotrol 12.5 (Hypochlorite solutions, UN1791, 8, III) from (1) 275-gallon plastic tote. The release was reportedly due to a loose cap and was contained to a 6 x 6 area of the trailer floor. No drains or waterways were affected by the release. Contractors were dispatched to clean up the release using absorbents and the proper PPE. The cap on the tote was tightened and forwarded on to the consignee. All waste debris generated was containerized in (1) 55-gallon poly drum. The waste drums were then transported offsite by contractors for proper disposal.
